Medical Ingredients.Hyaluronic Acid: It helps retain moisture in the skin by attracting water and is commonly found in moisturizers for dry skin.
Medical Ingredients.Ceramides: These are lipids that help maintain the skin's barrier and lock in moisture, preventing dryness.
Medical Ingredients.Urea: Urea is a humectant that helps the skin hold onto water and also has exfoliating properties to remove dead skin cells.
Medical Ingredients.Glycerin: Glycerin pulls moisture from the environment into the skin, helping it stay hydrated.
Medical Ingredients.Shea Butter: This natural fat derived from the shea tree is an emollient that provides deep hydration and nourishment for dry skin.
Medical Ingredients.Lanolin: This ingredient mimics the skin’s natural oils and provides a protective barrier to help retain moisture.
Medical Ingredients.Petrolatum: A strong occlusive that seals moisture into the skin, preventing further water loss.

Diet.Omega-3 Fatty Acids: These are found in fatty fish (like salmon, mackerel, and sardines), flaxseeds, chia seeds, and walnuts. Omega-3s help maintain the skin’s lipid barrier, which is essential for moisture retention.
Diet.Avocados: Rich in healthy fats and vitamin E, avocados can help keep skin supple and moisturized.
Diet.Water: Drinking enough water is critical for maintaining skin hydration. Aim for at least 8 glasses a day to keep your skin from drying out.
Diet.Herbal Teas: Green tea and other herbal teas contain antioxidants that can improve skin health while keeping you hydrated.
Diet.Vitamin E: Found in nuts, seeds, and spinach, vitamin E helps protect the skin from oxidative damage and keeps it moisturized.
Diet.Vitamin C: This powerful antioxidant (in citrus fruits, strawberries, bell peppers) helps with collagen production and can reduce skin dryness.
Diet.Beta-Carotene: Found in carrots, sweet potatoes, and spinach, beta-carotene converts into vitamin A, which is important for skin health.
Diet.Zinc: Shellfish, pumpkin seeds, and legumes contain zinc, which supports skin repair and keeps skin supple.
Diet.Bone Broth: Rich in collagen, bone broth can help improve skin elasticity and hydration over time.
Diet.Soy Products: Soy contains isoflavones, which can help improve skin texture and retain moisture.
Diet.Yogurt and fermented foods: These can improve gut health, which is linked to overall skin health, potentially reducing skin dryness and irritation.

Lifestyle.Use a Humidifier: Especially in colder months or dry climates, using a humidifier adds moisture to the air, preventing your skin from drying out.
Lifestyle.Avoid Hot Water: Long, hot showers strip the skin of its natural oils. Opt for lukewarm water and limit your shower time to 5-10 minutes.
Lifestyle.Use Gentle Soaps: Choose fragrance-free, mild cleansers that don’t strip your skin’s natural moisture barrier.
Lifestyle.Apply Moisturizer on Damp Skin: After a shower or washing your hands, apply a thick moisturizer while your skin is still damp to lock in moisture.
Lifestyle.Avoid Irritating Materials: Clothes made of wool or synthetic fibers can irritate dry skin. Opt for soft, natural fabrics like cotton that allow your skin to breathe.
Lifestyle.Use Hypoallergenic Detergents: Harsh laundry detergents can worsen dryness. Look for products that are free of dyes and fragrances.
Lifestyle.Wear Gloves in Cold Weather: Cold air can exacerbate dry skin, especially on your hands. Wear gloves when outside in the winter.
Lifestyle.Manage Stress Levels: Chronic stress can impact your skin health which sometimes cause dry patches. Incorporating relaxation techniques like meditation, yoga, or regular exercise can support skin health.
Lifestyle.Limit Exfoliation: Over-exfoliating can strip away your skin’s natural oils and worsen dryness. Opt for gentle exfoliants and use them sparingly (e.g., once a week).
Lifestyle.Stay Hydrated: Keeping your body hydrated internally helps maintain skin hydration as well.

Medical Ingredients.Salicylic Acid: his beta-hydroxy acid (BHA) penetrates into pores to help remove excess oil and dead skin cells, preventing breakouts and clogged pores.
Medical Ingredients.Niacinamide: Niacinamide helps regulate sebum production and reduce inflammation, making it great for controlling oiliness without over-drying. It also minimizes the appearance of pores and improves overall skin texture.
Medical Ingredients.Benzoyl Peroxide: Benzoyl peroxide helps reduce oil and kill acne-causing bacteria on the skin. It’s effective for treating and preventing breakouts.
Medical Ingredients.Alpha-Hydroxy Acids: AHAs, like glycolic acid or lactic acid, exfoliate the skin’s surface, removing dead cells and helping to clear excess oil and dirt from the pores.
Medical Ingredients.Clay: Clays absorb excess oil and mattify the skin. Masks or cleansers with kaolin or bentonite clay can help control shine and prevent clogged pores.
Medical Ingredients.Retinoids: Retinoids help regulate oil production and speed up cell turnover, preventing clogged pores and reducing breakouts. They also improve skin texture and reduce the appearance of large pores.
Medical Ingredients.Zinc: Zinc has anti-inflammatory and oil-regulating properties. It’s often found in topical creams and sunscreens for oily skin.
Medical Ingredients.Sulfur: Sulfur helps absorb excess oil while also having antimicrobial properties, making it useful for treating acne without irritating the skin.
Medical Ingredients.Tea Tree Oil: A natural antiseptic and anti-inflammatory ingredient, tea tree oil can reduce oiliness while also fighting acne-causing bacteria.
Medical Ingredients.Witch Hazel: Witch hazel is an astringent that can help reduce excess oil, tighten pores, and soothe the skin.
Medical Ingredients.Hyaluronic Acid: Although hyaluronic acid is known for hydrating, it’s great for oily skin because it provides moisture without adding extra oil, helping to balance the skin.

Diet.Omega-3 Fatty Acids: Omega-3s have anti-inflammatory properties that help balance oil production and reduce acne. They can also improve skin hydration without causing excess oil. Sources include fatty fish (salmon, mackerel, sardines), flaxseeds, chia seeds, walnuts.
Diet.Antioxidants: Antioxidants help reduce inflammation and combat oxidative stress, which can worsen oily skin and lead to breakouts. Sources include berries (blueberries, strawberries), leafy greens (spinach, kale), nuts, seeds, and green tea.
Diet.Low-Glycemic Foods: High-glycemic foods (those that cause spikes in blood sugar) can increase insulin levels, which may trigger excess oil production and acne. Eating low-glycemic foods helps regulate insulin levels, potentially reducing oiliness. Sources include whole grains (quinoa, oats, brown rice), legumes, vegetables (especially non-starchy ones like leafy greens, broccoli, and zucchini).
Diet.Limit Dairy Consumption: Some studies suggest that dairy, particularly skim milk, may be linked to acne and excess sebum production. This is due to the hormones found in dairy that can affect the skin’s oil production. Alternatives include plant-based milk (almond, soy, oat milk).
Diet.Zinc-Rich Foods: Zinc helps control sebum production and can reduce the severity of acne. It’s also involved in skin repair. Sources include shellfish, pumpkin seeds, chickpeas, cashews, and quinoa.
Diet.Probiotics: A healthy gut microbiome can influence skin health. Probiotics help regulate inflammation, potentially reducing acne and excess oil. Sources include yogurt with live cultures, kefir, sauerkraut, kimchi, and other fermented foods.
Diet.Green Tea: Green tea contains powerful antioxidants called catechins that help regulate oil production and reduce inflammation. Some studies have shown that drinking green tea can reduce sebum output.
Diet.Water: Drinking enough water helps maintain overall skin health and hydration. While oily skin produces excess sebum, it still needs hydration to stay balanced.
Diet.Vitamin A: Vitamin A helps reduce oil production and prevents clogged pores, which can lead to acne. It is also important for skin cell regeneration. Sources include carrots, sweet potatoes, spinach, and other orange and dark leafy vegetables.
Diet.Avoid Excessive Sugars and Processed Foo: Sugary and highly processed foods can cause inflammation and increase insulin levels, triggering more oil production and breakouts.

Lifestyle.Cleanse Your Face Twice a Day: Cleansing your skin in the morning and at night helps remove excess oil, dirt, and makeup. Opt for a gentle, non-comedogenic, and sulfate-free cleanser to avoid stripping the skin of its natural oils, which can lead to more oil production as a rebound effect. Washing too frequently can strip the skin and cause it to produce more oil. Stick to twice a day unless you’ve been sweating heavily.
Lifestyle.Use Oil-Free and Non-Comedogenic Product: Choose skincare products and makeup labeled as “oil-free” and “non-comedogenic” (which means they won’t clog your pores). This includes moisturizers, sunscreens, and foundations. Even oily skin needs moisture, so opt for lightweight, gel-based moisturizers that hydrate without adding extra oil.
Lifestyle.Blot Excess Oil Throughout the Day: Blotting papers are an easy way to remove excess oil during the day without stripping the skin. Press gently on oily areas (especially the T-zone) to reduce shine.
Lifestyle.Exfoliate Regularly (But Gently): Exfoliating helps remove dead skin cells and prevent clogged pores, which can contribute to oil buildup. Use gentle chemical exfoliants like salicylic acid or glycolic acid once or twice a week. Physical exfoliants (scrubs) can be too harsh and cause irritation. Exfoliating too often can lead to irritation and cause the skin to produce more oil in response.
Lifestyle.Stay Hydrated: Drinking enough water is important for overall skin health. Dehydrated skin can trigger more oil production as your skin tries to compensate for the lack of moisture.
Lifestyle.Manage Stress Levels: High stress levels can trigger increased sebum (oil) production, leading to more oily skin and acne. Incorporate stress management techniques like meditation, yoga, or regular exercise to help maintain balanced skin. Aim for 7-9 hours of sleep each night. Lack of sleep can disrupt hormone levels, leading to increased oil production.
Lifestyle.Exercise Regularly: Exercise boosts circulation and helps with skin detoxification by promoting sweat, which helps unclog pores. Make sure to cleanse your face immediately after exercising to prevent breakouts from sweat and oil buildup. Remove makeup before exercising to prevent it from mixing with sweat and clogging pores.
Lifestyle.Avoid Touching Your Face: Touching your face frequently transfers oil, bacteria, and dirt from your hands to your skin, which can clog pores and lead to more breakouts.
Lifestyle.Protect Your Skin from the Sun: Sun damage can cause the skin to dry out, leading to more oil production as the skin compensates for the moisture loss. Use a broad-spectrum sunscreen that is oil-free and non-comedogenic to protect your skin without making it greasy. Avoid heavy or greasy sunscreens and choose lightweight, gel-based formulations designed for oily skin.
